newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee ends up vs dollar on poor demand.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee ends up vs dollar on poor demand.

text.p: Lack of dollar demand on Tuesday pushed the Indian rupee up to close at 35.80/81 from the day's opening 35.825/835, dealers said.
The rupee traded at a high of 35.80 and a low of 35.83 in thin trade on Tuesday, they said.
"Quite a dull day...little dollar demand, good supplies," said a dealer at a state-run bank. "Volumes were quite poor."
He said the Reserve Bank of India bought dollars in small amounts at 35.805 rupees.
Dealers said the rupee was steady against the forward dollar in dull trade.
"The holiday mood seems to have gripped the market," said a dealer. "There was hardly any action today."
Dealers said the premia on six-month dollars ended Tuesday at 7.82 percent annualised against Monday's close of 7.76 percent.
There will be no forex transactions on Wednesday as banks are closed for Christmas. Trading resumes on Thursday.
